author: SimonT
title: Decentralization at Societal Level.
description: The staking experience does not make it easy to contribute to Cardano's goals of societal decentralization and support African SPO.

assessments.note: It is not entirely clear what the proposal is delivering. 30% of the funding is to set up a charity. What is that charity doing? The main project is to collect and publish data on African stake pool operators.

I think providing this information or even creating such a proposal can be useful after a solution to the "how we make Africa people buy Cardano" solved. From what I have understood, there are still large barriers between Africans and their possibilities to buy Cardano, and from this perspective, this seems like another step.

The decentralisation of stakepools and supporting SPOs is an important goal, however this proposal lacks concrete recommendations on how the cooperations are going to work and on what aspects the SPO evaluation system should be focused. I feel like the connection to the africa challenge is a bit loose.

The proposal is not very clearly written. While there are some parts of it that I like, the problem statement for example, others are not clearly explained, making it hard to visualise the entire plan.

The proposal is based on creating SPO more compatible with the different communities and cultures present in Africa, respecting the diversity of each one. Therefore, it seems to me a very relevant and promising idea, since SPO are essential for Cardano's activities to take place and most of them are concentrated, as the text itself says, in the USA and Europe. Through their creation in Africa, both the cotinent and the The Catalyst project would benefit.
The idea of supporting African pools is a great one, and societal integration would be beneficial for Cardano and clearly meets the goals of the challenge.

The project aims to "measure and report on the diversity of the SPO network" however it is planning to set up a charity in 3000$ and collect his information in 6000$. The information is already available in open domain and a 3000$ charity may not be the  correct manner to improve the Cardano SPOs diversity.
The project identified a real world problem but the offered solution doesn't solve the problem. I would recommend coming up with a different solution.

Impact - 4
This proposal strives to a address a critical need that must be addressed - how can the Cardano community actively promote and invest in societal diversity and equity in Africa, as well as other regions with little representation in current SPOs.  Addressing this need will help the Cardano community address the two objectives listed in the campaign brief: 
(1) Cardano is considered the best public block-chain operating in Africa; and 
(2) Cardano projects in Africa are not isolated but networked and growing.  
Cardano cannot be considered the best public block-chain operating in Africa if it lacks a critical mass of SPOs based in Africa; and supporting a critical mass of SPOs in Africa will provide an important network to support and grow Cardano projects throughout Africa.

The proposal's solutions offer a sound, general roadmap for addressing the problem identified. It would bring together a steering group of relevant, knowledgeable stakeholders; it would strive to understand and quantify current diversity; it would develop a new SPO evaluation, ranking system, and prototype tool to enable stake delegation that benefits representational and decentralization goals; and it would collaborate with staking information services. These are all excellent elements to include.

But my main concern is the proposal's description of what success looks like.  The proposal currently lists three descriptions:
1) Continuous measurement and reporting on Global and African level societal decentralisation,
2) Transparent, principled, objective based SPO recommendations, and
3) Increase African and Societal level decentralisation through adoption by staking information services (has dependencies).
As written right now, these descriptions of success are laudable, but also lack measureable criteria that can be used to measure the project's progress and success.  For example, what is the anticipated time necessary to execute the different solutions?  Is there a specific, measurable outcome that is desired as part of the SPO recommendations? A transparent, principled, and objective process is essential to any recommendation, but what is the desired outcome? (e.g. x number of people informed? y number of SPO's evaluated, etc). What is a reasonable increase in decentralisation, and in what timeframe? Additional SMART criteria (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic, & Time-related), could go a long way in offering concrete ways to evaluate the project's success.
Proposers appear to have the requisite experience. However the plan could have more details. What is the charity doing?
description of proposer seems to be legit, website works,

It is clear that the proposers have some experience with staking and stake pool operating. The plan is not very concrete and somewhat open ended, which makes it likely that something will be implemented, however the success criteria are very loose and milestones don't exist, so a lot needs to be formulated more concrete to ensure that what is implemented has high value.

The main focus of the proposal, the "Prototype of system to collect and describe diversity information of stake pool operators" is not described in detail, thus it would be hard to forecast its implementation.

In the proposal, the author claims to be a product manager at FAANG. It would be beneficial to include a website for that company, because different reviewers, like me, may not recognize it. In addition, we can find out, through an included website, who the other members of the team are: the ABC Stake Pool, which is made up of professionals with over 20 years of experience with cryptocurrencies. And on top of that they have a group on Telegram, in case anyone wants to ask questions. That is, they support the public very well, have a lot of experience and seem to be accessible and prepared to carry out the project.

The approach of the proposal to the problem is not entirely clear.  There is research and organization involved, and some proposed tools to help delegators find pools. I have some unadressed concerns. 1)Creating many African SPOs will not be sustainable without large delegations. 2) what are the standards for network/hardware quality? will pools run by Africans on global virtual server platforms be considered African, and would they really enhance the decentralization of Cardano? to me the goals of the proposal should happen organically over time and are difficult to bootstrap.  I think a small proposal including research and communication with African organizations, with a much smaller funding request, would present a more feasible initial step in future funding rounds.
The proposer is operating a well-established stake pool and will be able to implement the proposal.
This proposal doesn't include any details on team, team skills, or team relevant experience. Please describe the team that will implement this proposal.

I am providing a rating of a 2 to the project due to proposed creation of a charity.  Creating a charity is a nuanced and technical legal undertaking, regardless of country of origin or size of the proposed charity. None of the experience listed in the relevant experience section indicates anyone currently associated with the proposal has legal expertise, experience creating a charity, or experience running a charity; nor does the proposal indicate how the project would obtain this advice.  I may not have the same technical background as many in the Cardano community, but I do have legal training in the United States, and have had experience helping draft the articles of incorporation for a charity, obtaining a 501(c)(3) tax exemption from the IRS, and participating on the board of a charity for multiple years.  There are significant legal issues associated with charities that can sink a charity if they are not properly navigated.  Simply requesting $3,000 for the charity without further explanation of how those funds will be used or how the charity will be organized and run does not provide sufficient information to agree that the charity is a feasible component of the project. I agree the other aspects of the project are feasible; but because the charity is a significant part of the project budget, I cannot agree the project overall is feasible.

The proposal seems relatively simple. Gather and publish data on African stake pool operators to enable informed decision making regarding diversity. Should this information be integrated into options on the Daedelus stakepool ranking system?

"Increase African and Societal level decentralization through adoption by staking information services (has dependencies)" - this is a good metric, which can be used for multiple ways, yet not stated, such as increased number of stake pool operators or number of Cardano staked
Some of the criteria are difficult to quantify and no proper milestones are set. This proposal all in all is difficult to define and determine. Try making it more concrete next time.

The proposal definitely tackles an interesting subject, though it doesn't accomplish enough clarity to be able to be clearly assessed. I would suggest a re-writing for a future fund, if not backed in this one, as the idea in the problem statement is worthy of being remedied.

Much information is provided on how the plan would materialize. The authors explain by topic how they would solve the problem in question, that is, what steps they must follow in order to achieve their goals. These are also explained, and the financial amount requested is divided into 3 parts, each with its purpose. In addition, they outline plans for future work, which is very positive, as it shows the intention to continue the project. The only thing that could be added is a time schedule, that is, how many months each step would take place, possible delivery dates for results, etc., in order to facilitate the monitoring of the project. But other than that, everything is well cleared up.

The funds are directed to a 3 tasks.  3k is allocated to setting up a charity, but no details as to the jurisdiction or nature of this charity are given. 6k for the prototype of "system to collect and describe diversity information of stake pool operators" seems excessive without a more detailed description of the proposed product.  The remaining 1K is dedicated to hosting and operation of the product. I don't see a clear path from this proposal to the "What would success look like?" goals.
The proposal is unique and it is abstract to measure diversity in SPO distribution. It will be difficult to monitor and measure the progress of the project.
This proposal doesn't include any roadmap which makes it hard to audit. Please review the proposal and include a step by step roadmap.

I do not believe the information provided provides sufficient information to audit the progress and success of the proposal.  As mentioned earlier, the what does success look like section fails to contain concrete metrics like SMART criteria that can be used to measure outcomes within a specific timeframe.  I think the proposal is very close, and I think it would be beneficial to speak with some of the identified stakeholders now to try and identify some more specific criteria to measure what success would look like.  I also think the lack of information on the charity (other than the inclusion of $3,000 in the budget) makes it impossible to evaluate whether the charity will be a success. It's 30% of the budget, but it's only mentioned once in the entire proposal. What does the charity do? When will it be established? Where will it be established? Who is the charity serving? What does success look like for the charity? There is just not enough information provided to be able to reasonably audit the progress and success of the charity or the other proposal elements.
